overview.general: The Exit or Disposal Cost Obligations Topic addresses financial accounting and reporting for costs associated with exit or disposal activities, including but not limited to restructuring.
overview.scope: The guidance applies to all entities and covers transactions such as one-time employee termination benefits, costs to terminate contracts that are not leases, costs to consolidate facilities or relocate employees, costs associated with disposal activities covered by Subtopic 205-20, and exit activities including those related to newly acquired entities or acquisitions by not-for-profit entities. It excludes costs related to retirement of long-lived assets and impairment of unrecognized assets while in use.

objectives: The objective is to improve financial reporting by requiring recognition and initial measurement at fair value of liabilities for costs associated with exit or disposal activities only when the liability is incurred.
core_principles: A liability for exit or disposal costs is recognized only when incurred, not merely upon commitment to a plan.
Liabilities are initially measured at fair value when incurred.
Subsequent measurement uses the credit-adjusted risk-free rate.
Changes in estimates are recognized in the period of change.
Costs related to exit or disposal activities are presented in income from continuing operations unless related to discontinued operations.
Disclosure requirements include detailed information about the exit or disposal activity and associated costs.

sections.summary: Provides overview and background material for the guidance contained in the Subtopic, including typical situations addressed by the standards.

paragraphs.text: The Exit or Disposal Cost Obligations Topic addresses financial accounting and reporting for costs associated with exit or disposal activities. An exit activity includes but is not limited to a restructuring.

Those costs include, but are not limited to, the following: a. Involuntary employee termination benefits pursuant to a one-time benefit arrangement that, in substance, is not an ongoing benefit arrangement or an individual deferred compensation contract b. Costs to terminate a contract that is not a lease c. Other associated costs, including costs to consolidate or close facilities and relocate employees.

This Topic addresses when to recognize a liability for a cost associated with an exit or disposal activity. An entity's commitment to an exit or disposal plan, by itself, does not create a present obligation to others that meets the definition of a liability.

Certain postemployment benefit costs that may be associated with exit or disposal activities are covered by other Topics. The accounting for employee termination benefits will differ depending on whether the benefits are provided under a one-time benefit arrangement covered by this Topic or an ongoing benefit arrangement referred to in the following list. As indicated in paragraph 420-10-15-6, this Topic does not change the accounting for termination benefits covered by the following Topics and Subtopics: a. Postemployment benefits provided through a pension or postretirement benefit plan (Subtopics 715-30 and 715-60 specify the accounting for those costs.) b. Other nonretirement postemployment benefits covered by Topic 712 c. Special or contractual termination benefits covered by paragraphs 715-30-25-10 and 715-60-25-4 through 25-6 d. Individual deferred compensation arrangements that are addressed by paragraph 710-10-15-4(c) e. Stock compensation plans addressed by Topic 718.

sections.summary: Provides the high-level objectives that the Subtopic is intended to accomplish or attain.

paragraphs.text: The objective of the Exit or Disposal Cost Obligations Topic is to improve financial reporting by requiring that a liability for a cost associated with an exit or disposal activity be recognized and measured initially at fair value only when the liability is incurred.

sections.summary: Outlines the items to which the guidance applies or does not apply.

paragraphs.text: The Scope Section of the Overall Subtopic establishes the pervasive scope for the Exit or Disposal Cost Obligations Topic.
The guidance in the Exit or Disposal Cost Obligations Topic applies to all entities.

The guidance applies to termination benefits for involuntarily terminated employees under one-time benefit arrangements, costs to terminate non-lease contracts, costs to consolidate facilities or relocate employees, costs associated with disposal activities under Subtopic 205-20, and exit activities including those related to newly acquired entities or not-for-profit acquisitions.

An exit activity includes but is not limited to restructuring such as sale or termination of a line of business, closure or relocation of business activities, changes in management structure, and fundamental reorganization affecting operations.
key_terms: sale or termination of a line of business

paragraphs.text: The guidance does not apply to costs associated with retirement of long-lived assets covered by Subtopic 410-20 or impairment of unrecognized assets while being used.
Certain postemployment benefits are covered by other Topics. This Topic does not change accounting for termination benefits covered by Subtopics 715-30, 715-60, Topic 712, and others as specified.

sections.summary: Guidance on criteria, timing, and location for recording liabilities related to exit or disposal costs.

subsections.subsection_title: Determining When to Recognize a Liability

paragraphs.text: A liability for a cost associated with an exit or disposal activity shall be recognized in the period in which the liability is incurred, except as indicated in paragraphs 420-10-25-6 and 420-10-25-9 for one-time employee termination benefits incurred over time. If fair value cannot be reasonably estimated, recognition is deferred until fair value can be reasonably estimated.

requirements.requirement_text: A liability for a cost associated with an exit or disposal activity shall be recognized in the period in which the liability is incurred, except as indicated in paragraphs 420-10-25-6 and 420-10-25-9.
conditions: liability is incurred

requirements.requirement_text: If fair value cannot be reasonably estimated, the liability shall be recognized initially in the period in which fair value can be reasonably estimated.

paragraphs.text: A liability is incurred when the definition of a liability in FASB Concepts Statement No. 6 is met, meaning a present obligation exists due to a transaction or event leaving little or no discretion to avoid settlement. A commitment to an exit or disposal plan alone does not create a present obligation.
conditions: definition of a liability is met

paragraphs.text: Future operating losses expected in connection with an exit or disposal activity are recognized in the periods incurred but do not meet the definition of a liability themselves.

sections.summary: Guidance on derecognition of liabilities related to exit or disposal costs.

subsections.summary: If an event discharges or removes responsibility to settle a liability recognized in a prior period, the liability shall be reversed through the same income statement line item.

paragraphs.text: If an event or circumstance occurs that discharges or removes an entity's responsibility to settle a liability for a cost associated with an exit or disposal activity recognized in a prior period, the liability shall be reversed. The related costs shall be reversed through the same line item(s) in the income statement (statement of activities) used when those costs were recognized initially.

subsections.subsection_title: Exit or Disposal Activity Involving a Discontinued Operation
subsections.summary: Costs related to exit or disposal activities involving discontinued operations are included within discontinued operations results.

paragraphs.text: Costs associated with an exit or disposal activity involving a discontinued operation shall be included within the results of discontinued operations in accordance with Section 205-20-45.

subsections.summary: Costs related to exit or disposal activities not involving discontinued operations are included in income from continuing operations before income taxes.

paragraphs.text: Costs associated with an exit or disposal activity that does not involve a discontinued operation shall be included in income from continuing operations before income taxes in the income statement of a business entity and in income from continuing operations in the statement of activities of a not-for-profit entity (NFP). Separate presentation of exit and disposal costs in the income statement is not prohibited. If a subtotal such as income from operations is presented, it shall include the amounts of those costs.

sections.summary: Disclosure requirements for exit or disposal activities in notes to financial statements.

subsections.summary: Disclosures required in notes for periods including and following initiation of exit or disposal activities until completion.

paragraphs.text: All of the following information shall be disclosed in notes to financial statements that include the period in which an exit or disposal activity is initiated and any subsequent period until the activity is completed: a. A description of the exit or disposal activity, including the facts and circumstances leading to the expected activity and the expected completion date b. For each major type of cost associated with the activity (for example, one-time employee termination benefits, contract termination costs, and other associated costs), both of the following shall be disclosed: 1. The total amount expected to be incurred in connection with the activity, the amount incurred in the period, and the cumulative amount incurred to date 2. A reconciliation of the beginning and ending liability balances showing separately the changes during the period attributable to costs incurred and charged to expense, costs paid or otherwise settled, and any adjustments to the liability with an explanation of the reason(s) why. c. The line item(s) in the income statement or the statement of activities in which the costs in (b) are aggregated d. For each reportable segment, as defined in Subtopic 280-10, the total amount of costs expected to be incurred in connection with the activity, the amount incurred in the period, and the cumulative amount incurred to date, net of any adjustments to the liability with an explanation of the reason(s) why e. If a liability for a cost associated with the activity is not recognized because fair value cannot be reasonably estimated, that fact and the reasons why.

requirements.requirement_text: All of the following information shall be disclosed in notes to financial statements that include the period in which an exit or disposal activity is initiated and any subsequent period until the activity is completed: a. Description of the activity, b. For each major cost type: total expected, incurred in period, cumulative incurred, reconciliation of liability changes with explanations, c. Income statement line items where costs are aggregated, d. For each reportable segment: total expected, incurred, cumulative incurred with explanations, e. If liability not recognized due to inability to estimate fair value, that fact and reasons.
conditions: period in which an exit or disposal activity is initiated and any subsequent period until the activity is completed

paragraphs.text: Beginning with the period in which the exit plan is initiated, disclosure is required in all periods, including interim periods, until the exit plan is completed, covering description of the activity, costs expected and incurred, reconciliation of liabilities, income statement line items, reportable segments, and reasons if liabilities are not recognized due to inability to estimate fair value.

subsections.subsection_title: SEC Observer Comment: Classification of Inventory Markdowns and Other Costs Associated with Restructuring
subsections.summary: SEC Staff comments on classification of inventory markdowns related to restructuring.

paragraphs.text: Costs associated with exit or disposal activities not involving discontinued operations should be included in income from continuing operations before taxes. If a subtotal such as 'income from operations' is presented, it should include exit or disposal costs. Inventory markdowns attributable to exit or restructuring decisions are difficult to distinguish from those due to external market factors. Inventory markdowns are generally classified as cost of goods sold.

requirements.requirement_text: If a subtotal such as 'income from operations' is presented, that subtotal should include the amounts of exit or disposal costs.

paragraphs.text: The timing, method, and pricing of inventory dispositions are normal recurring activities. Inventory markdowns should be classified as a component of cost of goods sold.

requirements.requirement_text: Inventory markdowns should be classified in the income statement as a component of cost of goods sold.

glossary_terms.definition: The business or businesses that the acquirer obtains control of in a business combination. This term also includes a nonprofit activity or business that a not-for-profit acquirer obtains control of in an acquisition by a not-for-profit entity.

The entity that obtains control of the acquiree. However, in a business combination in which a variable interest entity (VIE) is acquired, the primary beneficiary of that entity always is the acquirer.

A transaction or other event in which a not-for-profit acquirer obtains control of one or more nonprofit activities or businesses and initially recognizes their assets and liabilities in the acquirer's financial statements. When applicable guidance in Topic 805 is applied by a not-for-profit entity, the term business combination has the same meaning as this term has for a for-profit entity. Likewise, a reference to business combinations in guidance that links to Topic 805 has the same meaning as a reference to acquisitions by not-for-profit entities.
Paragraphs 805-10-55-3A through 55-6 and 805-10-55-8 through 55-9 define what is considered a business.

A transaction or other event in which an acquirer obtains control of one or more businesses. Transactions sometimes referred to as true mergers or mergers of equals also are business combinations. See also Acquisition by a Not-for-Profit Entity.
The date the entity ceases using the right conveyed by the contract, for example, to receive future goods or services.
The date the plan of termination for one-time employee termination benefits meets all of the criteria in paragraph 420-10-25-4 and has been communicated to employees.
An agreement between two or more parties that creates enforceable rights and obligations.
A contract, or part of a contract, that conveys the right to control the use of identified property, plant, or equipment (an identified asset) for a period of time in exchange for consideration.
Any legal structure used to conduct activities or to hold assets. Some examples of such structures are corporations, partnerships, limited liability companies, grantor trusts, and other trusts.
The notification period that an entity is required to provide to employees in advance of a specified termination event as a result of an existing law, statute, or contract.

An entity that possesses the following characteristics, in varying degrees, that distinguish it from a business entity: a. Contributions of significant amounts of resources from resource providers who do not expect commensurate or proportionate pecuniary return b. Operating purposes other than to provide goods or services at a profit c. Absence of ownership interests like those of business entities. Entities that clearly fall outside this definition include the following: a. All investor-owned entities b. Entities that provide dividends, lower costs, or other economic benefits directly and proportionately to their owners, members, or participants, such as mutual insurance entities, credit unions, farm and rural electric cooperatives, and employee benefit plans.
Benefits provided to current employees that are involuntarily terminated under the terms of a one-time benefit arrangement.

A program that is planned and controlled by management, and materially changes either the scope of a business undertaken by an entity, or the manner in which that business is conducted, as defined by the International Accounting Standard No. 37 in 2002.
A legal entity subject to consolidation according to the provisions of the Variable Interest Entities.
